title: Problem Overview
content:
**Erdős Problem #581: Bipartite Subgraphs of Triangle-Free Graphs**

Let f(m) = guaranteed bipartite edges in any triangle-free graph with m edges.

**Question:** Determine f(m).

**Answer (Alon 1996):**
f(m) = m/2 + Θ(m^{4/5})

Triangle-free graphs are 'more bipartite' than arbitrary graphs.
mathContext: This connects extremal graph theory to probabilistic methods.

title: Triangle-Free Graph
content:
**IsTriangleFree:**

A graph G is triangle-free if no three vertices form a complete triangle (K₃).

Formally: ∀ a b c, ¬(Adj(a,b) ∧ Adj(b,c) ∧ Adj(a,c))

title: Bipartite Graph
content:
**IsBipartite:**

A graph is bipartite if vertices partition into two sets with all edges between them.

V = A ∪ B with A ∩ B = ∅ and all edges go A ↔ B.

title: Edge Count
content:
**edgeCount:**

Number of edges in a finite graph.

Used to parameterize the problem by m edges.

title: Subgraph
content:
**IsSubgraph:**

H is a subgraph of G if every edge of H is an edge of G.

∀ v w, H.Adj v w → G.Adj v w

title: Maximum Bipartite Edges
content:
**maxBipartiteEdges:**

Maximum number of edges in any bipartite subgraph of G.

This is what we want to lower-bound.

title: The Function f(m)
content:
**f(m):**

Minimum over all triangle-free graphs G with m edges of maxBipartiteEdges(G).

This is the guaranteed bipartite subgraph size - the worst-case best bipartite subgraph.

title: Trivial Lower Bound
content:
**half_edges_bipartite:**

Every graph has a bipartite subgraph with ≥ m/2 edges.

**Proof:** Random 2-coloring has expected m/2 bichromatic edges.

This is the baseline - triangle-freeness should help.

title: Problem Motivation
content:
**motivation:**

The trivial bound f(m) ≥ m/2 holds for ALL graphs.

**Question:** Does triangle-freeness give us MORE than m/2?

**Answer:** Yes, by Θ(m^{4/5})!

title: Alon's Upper Bound
Upper Bound Constant
content:
**c₂:**

The constant in the upper bound.

c₂_positive proves c₂ > 0.

title: Alon's Lower Bound
Lower Bound Constant
content:
**c₁:**

The constant in the lower bound.

c₁_positive proves c₁ > 0.

title: Theta Notation
content:
**ThetaBound:**

f(m) = m/2 + Θ(g(m)) means:
∃ c₁, c₂ > 0 such that c₁·g(m) ≤ f(m) - m/2 ≤ c₂·g(m)

The deviation from m/2 is precisely of order g(m).

title: Alon's Main Theorem
content:
**alon_main_theorem:**

f(m) - m/2 = Θ(m^{4/5})

Both upper and lower bounds match, giving tight asymptotics.

title: The Exponent 4/5
content:
**Why 4/5?**

This exponent arises from:
1. Triangle-free structure (Mantel: ≤ n²/4 edges)
2. Ramsey-theoretic considerations
3. Probabilistic decomposition arguments

It's not obvious why 4/5 - this is a deep result.
mathContext: The interplay between forbidden subgraphs and bipartiteness creates this specific exponent.

title: General Graph Bound
content:
**general_graph_bound:**

For any graph G, ∃ bipartite H ⊆ G with 2·|E(H)| ≥ |E(G)|.

This is the m/2 bound for arbitrary graphs - triangle-freeness gives the extra m^{4/5}.

title: Mantel's Theorem
content:
**mantel_theorem:**

A triangle-free graph on n vertices has ≤ n²/4 edges.

This classical 1907 result constrains triangle-free graph structure.

title: Kővári-Sós-Turán Theorem
content:
**KST_bound:**

Bipartite Turán bounds constrain triangle-free graphs.

|E(G)| ≤ (1/2)n^{3/2} + (1/4)n

This helps explain the 4/5 exponent.

title: Main Result
Historical Note
content:
**historical_note:**

Alon's proof used sophisticated probabilistic and algebraic methods.

Combinatorica 16 (1996): 301-311.

title: Reference
content:
**Reference:**

Alon, Noga. 'Bipartite subgraphs.'
Combinatorica 16 (1996): 301-311.
